skill.name: skill-developer
skill.description: Create and manage Claude Code skills following Anthropic best practices. Use when creating new skills, modifying skill-rules.json, understanding trigger patterns, working with hooks, debugging skill activation, or implementing progressive disclosure. Covers skill structure, YAML frontmatter, trigger types (keywords, intent patterns, file paths, content patterns), enforcement levels (block, suggest, warn), hook mechanisms (UserPromptSubmit, PreToolUse), session tracking, and the 500-line rule.

security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill containing markdown files. No executable code, no network operations, no file system access, and no environment variable access. Purely educational content about Claude Code skill management.

content.value_statement: Claude Code skills automate best practice enforcement and provide contextual guidance. This skill teaches you to create skills with auto-activation, triggers, and guardrails that enhance AI assistance.
actual_capabilities: Create skill files with YAML frontmatter and proper structure
Configure triggers using keywords, intent patterns, file paths, and content patterns
Set enforcement levels (block, suggest, warn) for skill behavior
Implement skip conditions with session tracking and file markers
Debug skill activation issues with manual hook testing
Apply Anthropic best practices including the 500-line rule
limitations: Skill files are markdown documentation only, not executable code
This skill provides guidance, not code execution capabilities
Hook implementation requires separate TypeScript files not included here
Skills are specific to Claude Code platform

best_practices: Keep SKILL.md under 500 lines using progressive disclosure with reference files
Include all trigger keywords in the description for automatic activation
Test patterns with real prompts before documenting to avoid false positives
anti_patterns: Using overly generic keywords like 'system' or 'create' causes false positives
Making patterns too specific results in missed triggers (false negatives)
Nesting reference files deeper than one level reduces discoverability

faq.question: What is the difference between guardrail and domain skills?
faq.answer: Guardrail skills use 'block' enforcement to prevent errors. Domain skills use 'suggest' enforcement for guidance.

faq.question: How many trigger types does the skill system support?
faq.answer: Four types: keywords (substring match), intent patterns (regex), file paths (glob), and content patterns (regex).

faq.question: Can I disable a skill temporarily?
faq.answer: Yes. Set environment variable SKIP_SKILL_GUARDRAILS to disable all, or skill-specific vars like SKIP_DB_VERIFICATION.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using skills?
faq.answer: Skills only read their own markdown files. They cannot access user files, credentials, or make network requests.

faq.question: Why is my skill not triggering?
faq.answer: Check keyword matching, test hooks manually with echo and npx tsx, verify JSON syntax with jq, and confirm skill names match.

faq.question: How does this compare to Claude's built-in prompts?
faq.answer: Skills provide automatic activation based on context, while built-in prompts require manual selection. Skills support enforcement.
